R Series Episode 2:
Creating Awesome Web Slides in Quarto with Revealjs

Dr. Kam Tin Seong
Assoc. Professor of Information Systems

School of Computing and Information Systems,
Singapore Management University

10 Feb 2026

Why you are here?

Because you are:

  • tired of creating PowerPoint slides

  • interested to create awesome web slides using R.

What you may not know?

html5

JavaScript

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets)

Quarto Presentation Slide

Do you know that Quarto presentation slides are web-enabled?

Quarto Presentation Slide

But Slidy presentation slides can be rather boring

Introducing revealjs

Let’s get started

  • Launch RStudio.
  • Select File -> New File -> Quarto Presentation

Creating a Revel JS presentation

  • Click on Create button.

Editing the YAML

Editing the front page

Edit the default to as shown below.

  • Delete the rest of the default text.
  • Save the Quarto Presentation file
  • Knit the newly saved qmd file.

Modifying display aspect ratio

  • Edit line 8 and 9

  • Save the Quarto file and knit the document.

Making slides

  • Slide 1 starts where YAML ends

  • 3 dashes in a row — on a line by itself is a new slide.

Incremental reveals

There are two ways to set incremental reveals.

  • global setting editing the yaml.

  • local setting

Hello plot

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, knitr, DT) 

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="light blue") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

The code chunk is way too small. Increase the font size please!

Dividing the page

Dividing the page

I am on the left!

pacman::p_load(tidyverse) 

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="light blue") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

I am on the right!

Working with Tabsets

  • The code chunk
  • The plot
pacman::p_load(tidyverse) 

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="light blue") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

This is what you need!

Adding Table

Static html table

head(exam_data) %>% 
  knitr::kable(format = "html")
ID CLASS GENDER RACE ENGLISH MATHS SCIENCE
Student321 3I Male Malay 21 9 15
Student305 3I Female Malay 24 22 16
Student289 3H Male Chinese 26 16 16
Student227 3F Male Chinese 27 77 31
Student318 3I Male Malay 27 11 25
Student306 3I Female Malay 31 16 16

Interactive table

datatable(exam_data, 
          options = list(pageLength = 5, autoWidth = TRUE))

Themes

There are 11 built-in themes provided for Reveal presentations. They are:

  • beige
  • blood
  • dark
  • default
  • league
  • moon
  • night
  • serif
  • simple
  • sky
  • solarized

You can also create your own themes.
